document.title: Common Core State Standards for Mathematics

7CA168EC9F164D1E8A22F468B4519666.description: Construct and interpret two-way tables summarizing data for two categorical variables collected from the same source, calculate relative frequency for rows or columns, and analyze the table for possible association between two variables. (8.SP.A.4)

F050CB8F4DAF4A2B824F723518F56045.description: Sketch a scatter plot of bivariate data, calculate and graph the line of best fit (if the data shows a linear correlation and if not, why not), interpret the slope and y-intercept, and calculate and analyze the correlation coefficient. (8.SP.A.2, 8.SP.A.3)

926425BC6A15451485FF31F94BB2AE60.description: Construct scatter plots for bivariate measurement data. Investigate, describe and interpret patterns inherent in scatter plots, such as clusters, outliers, positive, negative or no correlation, linear and non-linear relations. (8.SP.A.1, 8.SP.A.2)

A595520A25AE41AC8B6E80396ED6FAE8.description: Students will investigate patterns of association in bivariate data in mathematical and real world problems.

F6A80C9138024A219A9FB3676672D9C0.description: Determine the impact on volume for any given change in radius or height in mathematical or real world problems. (8.G.C.9)

C29311FEA3DE4FEFA2D299A1D72D814A.description: Use the formulas for surface area of cylinders, cones, spheres, composite solids, prisms and pyramids in mathematical or real world problems. (WS)

8A772DB38D8C4A5BA5942C2E8314349E.description: Find the volume of composite solids in mathematical or real world problems. (8.G.C.9, WS )

C5FE14E434364E1285489BEB8D0F5195.description: Memorize and apply the formula for volume of spheres in mathematical or real world problems. (8.G.C.9)

1CAA00343DCA4E09B5FB7316697AC16F.description: Construct, memorize and apply the formula for volume of cylinders in mathematical or real world problems. (8.G.C.9)

32CE394ADDAB40DE8FF4C7EC7D260CD0.description: Construct, memorize and apply the formula for volume of cones in mathematical or real world problems.   (8.G.C.9)

A3C8A623FB064FFE8550D973F1263B59.description: Students will use volume formulas to solve mathematical and real world problems for cylinders, cones and spheres.

60B00E30416F41BBAA1540BD84F7B057.description: Given two or more two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence of transformations in which one figure is the image of the other geometric figure. (8.G.A.3, 8.G.A.4)

EF5D8CFB3EB0440B96DCF07D54CF2756.description: Find the coordinates of an image after a series of dilations, translations, rotations and/or reflections of an original two-dimensional figure (both graphically and mathematically) and informally prove that the geometric figures are congruent or similar. (8.G.A.3)

599F33D60FA04E719B677C5E8FCC972D.description: Identify the characteristics of geometric dilations. Calculate, draw and/or write the image coordinates after one or more dilations and informally prove that the geometric figures are similar figures. (8.G.A.4).

E1EAA1BD2F474AACB156D575C841643B.description: Identify the characteristics of geometric rotations. Calculate, draw and/or write the image coordinates after one or more rotations and informally prove that the geometric figures are congruent. (8.G.A.1, 8.G.A.2, 8.G.A.3)

567E2033DF3B4FE89F871C40CAEF6102.description: Identify the characteristics of geometric reflections. Calculate, draw and/or write the image coordinates after one or more reflections and informally prove that the geometric figures are congruent. (8.G.A.1, 8.G.A.2, 8.G.A.3)

09559DD7CF804EEB9237923DCA13B17B.description: Identify the characteristics of geometric translations. Calculate, draw and/or write the image coordinates after one or more translations and informally prove that the geometric figures are congruent. (8.G.A.1, 8.G.A.2, 8.G.A.3 )

1EC95522A0A34A0B961D96F4A424CB4C.description: Students will identify and perform geometric transformations on a two dimensional plane, and describe the effect of the transformation, including congruence and/or similarity.

A50759C2BAA84BF3B3DA4672669A78BA.description: Perform mathematical calculations using all math operations for numbers in scientific notation, choose appropriate units of measurement, and analyze the results in the context of mathematical and real world problems. (8.EE.A.4)

87D18742D1AD4AC78BB1DD74B4C4E803.description: Compare and contrast (including estimation) the size of very small and large numbers in scientific notation and calculate how many times larger or smaller one number is versus the other. (8.EE.A.3)

1C166D933B0F473EB3BE05B4FB52E33C.description: Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology (calculator, computer, etc.). (8.EE.A.4, WS)

3DE4710AC9204DC5BCEC8DBA09B15A3E.description: Identify numbers written in scientific notation and convert large and small numbers between scientific notation and standard form. (8.EE.A.3)

FFAA62E5D0904372B315FE9168369E5C.description: Identify the pattern inherent in the following properties and use these properties to generate equivalent numerical and algebraic expressions: (8.EE.A.1) Product of powers property (bmbn=bm+n), Power of a power property ((bm)n=bmn), Quotient of powers property (bmbn=bm-n), Power of a product ((ab)n=anbn), Power of a quotient property ((a/b)n=an/bn), Zero power property (any number to the zero power =1), Negative exponent property (b-n=1/bn), Negative exponent property for fractions ((x/y)-n=(y/x)n)

87BEFA7B2FB44A11B7AD25FEC06483E1.description: Students will a) simplify numerical and algebraic expressions with integer exponents and b) compare/contrast and perform math operations in scientific notation for mathematical and real world problems.

768D822E84F04568A7AB01665EED2CD5.description: Analyze and solve real world problems by writing and solving a system of two linear equations in two variables. (8.EE.C.8.C)

EAAF0EDB86FB4DD89D40C5C2F5448FB2.description: Examine a system of linear equations, determine and justify the best method to solve, and solve the system. (8.EE.C.8.B)

C6E0017065824A4085905E21B5B1A0EA.description: Determine whether a system of equations has no solution, one solution or an infinite number of solutions by inspection (simple equations)and/or justify answer algebraically. (8.EE.C.8.B)

271B69204B3640E4A72C0ABCD254113D.description: Use technology to graph and solve systems of equations. (WS)

10478DB4629E4D87AB28383B714DFB31.description: Write and solve systems of two linear equations using the elimination or linear combination method. (8.EE.C.8.B)

91B7FC3BEDCE402FAD3EA3C6E2FE59FF.description: Write and solve systems of two linear equations using the substitution method. (8.EE.C.8.B)

91E5CB0B8AA04B1A8C8CE4C5866AE5B2.description: Write and solve systems of equations by graphing and determine that the solution corresponds to the point (or points) of intersection of their graphs as that point (or points) satisfy both equations simultaneously. (8.EE.C.8.A)

291568D19C614DE9B19B8ADD2A0A5CF1.description: Students will determine the best method to solve a system of linear equations, write and solve the system and analyze the solution(s) in mathematical and real world problems.

0B1699CBA06247CC835E63D21A423DD8.description: Identify similar triangles based on corresponding angle congruence and/or side measurement proportionality, and use angle-angle criterion to write and solve equations to find missing measurements in similar triangles (with supporting informal arguments). (8.G.A.5, WS)

25F9B3431DAA47218BA821E8F3A60F2D.description: Use the relationships between the a) sum of the interior angles of a polygon and b) the sum of the exterior angles of a polygon, to write and solve equations to find the measures of interior and exterior angles of polygons (with supporting informal arguments). (8.G.A.5, WS)

A1D1B7AD4A604985B944906017A3CF6D.description: Identify interior and exterior angles of triangles, and use their relationships to write and solve equations to find the interior and exterior angles of triangles (with supporting informal arguments). (8.G.A.5)

B269348BF8EA41DA87FC1F34C6B2DF5D.description: Identify parallel and transversal lines, name the angles formed, and calculate the measure of each angle (with supporting informal arguments) when parallel lines are cut by a transversal (8.G.A.5)

46746E0DA14A4E78BD24E93A7C84B22A.description: Students will use informal arguments to establish a) the angle measurement for parallel lines cut by a transversal, b) the angle sum relationships for triangles and polygons, and c) the angle-angle criterion for similar triangles.

470769DD07F44434A21A419A6858B8A2.description: Identify non-linear functions presented in various formats, provide examples of non-linear functions and compare and contrast linear and non-linear functions. For example, the function A=s2 is not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1,), (2,4) and (3,9) which are not on a straight line. (8.F.A.3)

FC8067366455445C8B817228C06F8742.description: Sketch (to various levels of precision) the qualitative features of a function that have been described verbally. (8.F.B.5)

4CF437C5101144CE93F644B8D05ED8EE.description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing their graphical representation (increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). (8.F.B.5)

BC7ED18E1DE242FDAE0CFE8596207382.description: Write the standard form of a linear equation, graph the equation and interpret the slope and intercepts in the context of mathematical or real world problems. (WS)

F45AD4EBE5464FFBAD7B69DE47DCA7EA.description: Write the slope-intercept form (including function form) of a linear equation, graph the equation and interpret the slope and y-intercept in the context of mathematical or real world problems. (7.RP.A.2.C, 8.EE.B.5)

0674722DA8F642E4810EBA006E43C8CB.description: Write the point-slope form of a linear equation, graph equation in point-slope form, and interpret the slope in the context of mathematical or real world problems. (8.EE.B.5, WS)

0A779DA52A3844B39870A86ADF29E370.description: Write, evaluate and compare equations in function notation for data in various formats (verbal descriptions, table of values, graphs and algebraically). (8.F.A.2, 8.F.B.4, WS)

81980E2F947C4C1584368DB60A84CDC8.description: Define relations versus functions; construct and examine tables, graphs, and mapping diagrams to determine whether a relation represents a function. (8.F.A.1, 8.F.A.2, WS)

B6253DA098834D77BDD64D856735C061.description: Students will a) identify, compare, and write linear functions, b) write various forms of linear equations/functions and interpret the characteristics in the context of mathematical and real world problems, c) analyze and/or sketch graphs to describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities, and d) compare and contrast linear vs. non-linear functions.

452AEBF2CDC746C5B18B7F504E7BEFF6.description: Identify characteristics of parallel and perpendicular lines and graph them. (8.EE.B.5, WS)

6583E7312E00477BBC38E1AE78BEA4D6.description: Compare and contrast two or more linear relationships in different formats by calculating and comparing their slopes (or rate of change). For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed. (8.EE.B.5, 8.F.A.2)

308D3CAAC5974CAE9EAD82F3DC8D38FD.description: Use similar triangles to demonstrate and explain why a) the slope or rate of change in any line is the same between any two distinct points; b) horizontal lines have a slope of zero and c) vertical lines have an undefined slope. (8.EE.B.6)

B635CCC20592438584AE9AFC23B5B060.description: Calculate the slope of a line by counting/calculating the vertical over horizontal change for data (ordered pairs, graph, table of values) and/or using the formula yx given any two points and describe and compare the slope (i.e. positive vs. negative, greater or smaller slope). (8.EE.B.5, WS)

F28EBD1667D34C3BB586262E9FF1E292.description: Graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form using the slope and y-intercept values, and interpret the slope and y-intercept in the context of the problem. (8.EE.B.6, WS)

0F43FC317F064F749CECC3FD9DA481FF.description: Graph a linear equation in standard form by calculating the x- and y- intercepts, and interpret the intercepts in the context of the problem. (8.EE.B.5, WS)

62CD12F275954337A10FA9A4D6D5146A.description: Graph linear equations (including horizontal and vertical lines) using a table of values and determine that the graphed line represents all solutions to the equation. (8.EE.B.5, WS)

A38EA09F125243F7A172DD0ADDE64DCF.description: Students will a) graph linear equations, b) identify, calculate and compare the unit rate of change or slope in various formats (graphs, tables, etc.) and c) identify characteristics of and graph parallel and perpendicular lines.

3B28B9C43E8148DE8AC05E7978EDA2D6.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem and the distance formula to find the distance between any two points in mathematical and real world problems, and interpret the solution in the problem context. (8.G.B.8, WS)

FD4EE8240CBC4D48B5FAF1AA8E654FF8.description: Memorize the Pythagorean Theorem and apply it in determining unknown side lengths of right triangles in two and three dimensions. (8.G.B.7)

126235435AE84E2F8F81EE79CE572CDD.description: Construct and explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse. (8.G.B.6)

987F1F07891242C3948E095D7E45FE1E.description: Approximate the value of expressions involving irrational numbers, compare and order them on a number line (using rational numbers as estimates for irrational numbers), and estimate the value of expressions and equations containing irrational numbers. (8.NS.A.2)

19D27F8CB0B5445896ED658C0C1B5126.description: Classify numbers into the appropriate number systems and determine which system is most precise; discern that any real number is either rational or irrational, and that a rational number terminates or repeats when written in decimal form. (8.NS.A.1)

B65846A1FD9D49279DA504DB1DB727F0.description: Evaluate expressions and solve equations involving perfect cubes and cube roots in mathematical and real world problems and interpret the solution within the problem context. (8.EE.A.2)

AA6D3655C54F4C538835593EDDCBC3D2.description: Evaluate expressions and solve equations involving perfect squares and square roots in mathematical and real world problems and interpret the solution within the problem context. (8.EE.A.2)

62E0955263204EADA4650D2F5A1E6AC5.description: Students will classify real numbers, evaluate expressions, and solve equations containing radical numbers, including the Pythagorean Theorem, in mathematical and real world problems.

F6C3563ED5ED44D5A400F99C9027F0BF.description: Rewrite equations to solve for one variable in terms of the other variable(s). (WS)

D914BF5B26644A0D9635A6F945570679.description: Create examples of linear equations with one solution, no solution and infinite solutions. (8.EE.C.7.A)

C18393C684EB407491AD7AD6B5CF09D5.description: Interpret an equation as having one solution, no solution or infinite solutions by transforming a given equation into simpler form, until an equivalent equation is in the form x = a, a = a or a = b (where a and b are different numbers). (8.EE.C.7.A)

B420B6E38A58412BA52116001AC4946F.description: Write and solve one variable multi-step equations with rational number coefficients requiring the use of the distributive property, combining like terms and/or simplifying equations with variables on both sides. (8.EE.C.7.B)

96C426B7ACD14AA6986A4BC2C55D5FC7.description: Students will write, analyze and solve multi-step linear equations with rational number coefficients in mathematical and real world problems.

FC73FBC8D1F64C21B2381C30D434B53C.description: Describe and explain the amount of overlap of two numerical data distributions, both visually (i.e. comparing dot plots) as well as mathematically by measuring the difference between the measures of center and variability of the two sets of data. For example, the mean height of basketball players is 79.75 inches vs. mean height of soccer players is 72.07 inches, resulting in a difference of 7.68 inches. The mean absolute deviation is 2.14 for basketball players and 2.53 for soccer players, indicating moderate variation in both sets of data. (7.SP.B.3, 7.SP.B.4, WS)

FDB40360276C4BC49AAB779D270DFA16.description: Explain how specific outliers affect the measures of central tendency within a given data set. (WS)

E8AC1A2A080F4C4EA99683CE9425B849.description: Create generalizations and draw inferences using data from a random sample of a population. (7.SP.A.2)

346C9AF290B44EEEA303AC549D79CCB8.description: Define and give examples of population, determine if a sample of a population is unbiased or biased, and that conclusions about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is unbiased. (7.SP.A.1, 7.SP.A.2)

14147DE0EDD04FAAA9DD3EBA7713EDB6.description: Students will use random sampling to draw informal comparative inferences about populations in mathematical and real world problems.

2A43453D880B4FA1B851993980B69C3A.description: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events. For example, use random digits as a simulation tool to approximate the answer to the question: If 40% of donors have type A blood, what is the probability that it will take at least 4 donors to find one with type A blood? (7.SP.C.8.C)

A236021B5FC04DE5B1D250C2B061C168.description: Identify when an experiment is uniform versus not uniform, articulating the factors that may affect the uniformity of the model. For example, when choosing marbles out a bag, a uniform experiment would have all marbles equally sized, whereas larger marbles would make the experiment nonuniform. (7.SP.C.7.A)

9C5A44C8560243FD92CF2606002B9DEC.description: Calculate the theoretical and experimental probability of compound events using organized lists, diagrams, tables, and/or simulations, and distinguish between independent and dependent events. (7.SP.C.8, 7.SP.C.8.A)

665D1D2EABFE4BBDAFEA1B56D2F296C3.description: Calculate the experimental probability of simple events by collecting data from a probability experiment. Explain what the experimental probability represents and that as the number of trials increase, the experimental probability approaches theoretical probability. (7.SP.C.6, 7.SP.C.7.B)

3243B60B9D864F0C97953BC5E6945F79.description: Express the probability of a chance event as a number between 0 and 1 and interpret that larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. (7.SP.C.5)

1E37FDF891314D76AF9C395AE82BC720.description: Students will develop, calculate, and evaluate probability events in mathematical and real world problems.

1AC041CF41864910A205B8BA91CFBCEF.description: Construct a triangle, with given conditions, and determine and justify how many triangles could be created. (7.G.A.2)

91C3C0B6692F44CF8469C53E30E9CEE7.description: Construct scale drawings of geometric figures, given actual lengths and a scale. (7.G.A.1)

E9F5C296EC4048A690DA413CF582DD31.description: Solve problems involving computing between actual and scale drawings to find missing lengths and areas. (7.G.A.1)

B22751935019485181F43BF9F902D857.description: Determine both the scale and scale factor between an object and its scale drawing. (7.G.A.1)

39F4BD8732FC425BA31F4E894B739221.description: Identify supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles, and use their relationships to write and solve equations to find missing value(s) in a given geometric figure. (7.G.B.5)

FF7C9D6765D142C5B786A80F5833E42D.description: Students will construct geometric figures, and justify the relationships between them, including scale representations, in mathematical and real world problems.

65FE42E7F0434C22BA18815C5179D88A.description: Use the simple interest formula to find interest earned and/or paid, annual interest rates, time, and/or principal amounts in mathematical and real world problems. (7.RP.A.3)

DD765E0616E54D69B5D554EB66818D9F.description: Calculate prices/values in mathematical and real world problems (ie markups and markdowns; tax; gratuities, fees, and commissions). (7.RP.A.3)

C8CF01C4746A48A6B52EFD8E4CE0A267.description: Calculate percent increases, decreases, and/or error in mathematical and real world problems. (7.RP.A.3)

F976E2646B0047109485FCBFB6246CF6.description: Use the percent equation to find parts, wholes, and percents in percent problems. (7.RP.A.3)

E85D8786498E4FD6963313603C368678.description: Use the percent proportion to find parts, wholes, and percents in percent problems. (7.RP.A.3)

68C49C158F89482EBF1430953CBA2038.description: Students will write and solve proportional relationships (simple interest, tax, markups/markdowns, percent increase/decrease, and percent error) in mathematical and real world problems

4C34F25657C249618410DA2D8D7B601D.description: Use proportional relationships to solve real world problems involving rates and ratios. (7.RP.A)

4A268622AE4B4195817BD2E0B8B18C1F.description: Explain what a point (x,y) on a graph of a proportional relationship means in a given situation, with special emphasis on (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate. (7.RP.A.2.D)

9014CCAE664E46D09434EF66891CFB85.description: Identify the constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships. (7.RP.A.2.B)

6854DA387F31403D89FADE0D70A030DD.description: Determine whether two quantities are in a proportional relationship by testing equivalent ratios in tables or observing whether a graph is a straight line through the origin. (7.RP.A.2.A)

D92AC05CE8BC4D9EA0A412215C31DBD8.description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions measured in like or different units and use unit rate to solve problems. For example, if a person walks  mile in each  hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction 12/14 miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour. Then determine how far a person would walk in 3  hours. (7.RP.A.1)

DA1F608D527B4ACFA2EFFDD93FF3FC3C.description: Students will analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve mathematical and real world problems.

CC9BAFD37F88472080A3946CB3FB8D22.description: Determine and name the two-dimensional figure that results from taking a cross-section (vertical, horizontal, or slanted slice) of a 3-D solid. (7.G.A.3, WS)

52C8E1F361494AC5AD6C4F5651FBC3ED.description: Calculate the surface area of pyramids and prisms by deconstructing into simple shapes in mathematical and real world problems. (7.G.B.6)

704D4459C3954F00B19F59AB86F2283D.description: Construct, memorize, and apply the formulas for volume of pyramids and prisms in mathematical and real world problems. (7.G.B.6)

1CC909B22E04445585939D606B3F230B.description: De-construct polygons and complex figures into simple shapes (including circles) in order to calculate area in mathematical and real world problems. (7.G.B.6)

DFF68009866C4DF98B9A610A67F0EF1C.description: Construct and apply the formulas for area and circumference of a circle, and describe the relationship between the formulas. (7.G.B.4)

1F253E07E2984C81994E0E46825C89AD.description: Students will solve mathematical and real world problems involving a) the area and circumference of circles and complex figures; b) the volume and surface area of prisms and pyramids; and c) the cross-section of a 3-D solid.

BECB20138579467BA4DBF8A7443B0F45.description: Assess whether answers to equations and inequalities make sense in the context of the problem using mental math and estimation. (7.EE.B.3)

15CA8B6E01DE4BB086BB9BC780923579.description: Write and solve two-step inequalities in mathematical and real world problems. Interpret the solution in the context of the problem (including possible rounding and using appropriate units). (7.EE.B.4.B)

A3F4F21EB7AF449BB5CB6BFC6F6CE80E.description: Solve two-step inequalities (in the form of px+qr, px+qr and px+qr) where p, q, and r are rational numbers, and graph the solutions on a number line. (7.EE.B.4.B)

7C50A80513D245D9967FBBF83D739DF9.description: Solve multi-step equations requiring the use of properties of operations and/or combining like terms, where p, q, and r are integers. For example, solve 8(x + 9) - 3x + 2 = 34 (7.EE.A.4.A, 8.EE.C.7)

2B3896BD54C84FD28EA748D913FBED78.description: Write and solve two-step equations given real world problems. Interpret the solution in the context of the problem (including possible rounding and using appropriate units). (7.EE.B.4.A)

1AD0A140B70940909533CAACF9A2918D.description: Solve two-step equations (in the form of px+q=r and p(x+q)=r) where p, q, and r are rational numbers. (7.EE.B.4.A.).

53A9440A4FF34D22B26BACAB7B132E4D.description: Students will a) write and solve two-step and multi-step equations; and b) write, solve, and graph two-step inequalities, in mathematical and real world problems.

5B14E792295E490CBA907AD6754ECF6D.description: Factor expressions (with rational number coefficients) in equivalent forms to show how quantities are related. For example, 12x-5 =12(x-10) (7.EE.A.2)

73CC5E49460B43C49804336E1B0C8850.description: Use properties, including the distributive property, to expand and simplify expressions into equivalent forms with rational coefficients. For example, 3(x-4)+3x = 3x -12+3x =6x-12 . (7.EE.A.1)

3F622BDDE0DD48DF8316A5A93AF28166.description: Identify and combine like terms to simplify algebraic expressions. (7.EE.A.1)

1114CB28F6554C7F9D3FA0A6DB693EE4.description: Students will represent and evaluate mathematical and real world problems using algebraic expressions.

8FCD41534AE643598CA352D151F2B232.description: Solve mathematical and real world problems involving the four operations with rational numbers, and interpret the solution in the context of the problem (including possible rounding and using appropriate units). (7.NS.A.3)

9E3760CDCDA54E958289435716EE2547.description: Identify examples of rational numbers as numbers that can be represented in the form ab where a and b are integers and b0, and as decimals that terminate or repeat. (7.NS.A.2.D)

26689CF13ADF4819986575491A241B7F.description: Identify equivalent negative fractions. For example, -ab=a-b=-ab . (7.NS.A.2.B)

36484D846E074F11BF240FA184285426.description: Apply properties of operations for rational numbers to solve addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division problems. (7.NS.A.2.A, 7.NS.A.2.C, 7.NS.A.3)

09F56710FD8D49C9B054D339E4FCF189.description: Students will perform operations involving rational numbers to solve mathematical and real world problems.

03C9040D17334F76AADD62DCE8EF2363.description: Given numerical data from real world problems, summarize the data and patterns in relation to its context, by giving and analyzing measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (range, interquartile range). (6.SP.5c, 6.SP.5d)

7E6C9A1CB6F64E2191246191417F9F9A.description: Given numerical data from real world problems, summarize the data in relation to its context and the nature of the attribute, including what is being measured (i.e. weight of puppies), number of observations (i.e. 10 puppies were weighed), unit of measurement (kg, lbs.) and how it was measured (i.e. weigh on a scale). (6.SP.A.5.A, 6.SP.A.5.B)

CDF7CCC7D25D4996949B1EA2501DB3C7.description: Given numerical data from mathematical and real world problems, display the data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box and whisker plots. (6.SP.A.4)

8B7189094BC044798BD3606B3D675AD6.description: Describe the distribution of a set of data by its center, spread, and overall shape. (6.SP.A.2)

F77248AEE229418E843567D140A66E70.description: Identify and calculate measures of variability (maximum, minimum, range and interquartile range) and use these measures to describe how values of a data set vary. (6.SP.A.3)

513A250CDBCC4563A326695EC031B93B.description: Identify and calculate measures of center (mean, median, and mode), use these measures to describe a data set and specify which is the best representation of a set of data. (6.SP.A.3)

F8ABC3F0689F4F58B3DA604A9E786E9A.description: Identify a statistical question as one that anticipates variability. For example, How old am I? is not a statistical question, whereas How old are the students in my school? is a statistical question. (6.SP.A.1)

021E0C1ECA0442698C6033A5825DE1E4.description: Students will summarize and describe sets of data by identifying and analyzing distribution, measures of center, and statistical variability.

204ACDA484374263A55F5282B26A2A07.description: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices and use coordinates to calculate the length of horizontal and vertical sides in the context of solving mathematical and real world problems. (6.G.A.3)

09BD34FD139B409096E608E1762879C5.description: Identify and describe the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using tables, graphs and equations. (6.EE.B.9)

521B113D2506482AA42FD78F84A31838.description: Represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another using tables, graphs and equations with two variables. (6.EE.B.9)

FBB3B312FC3945C3983650C9F779901E.description: Identify and describe the characteristics of the four quadrants in the coordinate plane and graph coordinates containing integers on the coordinate plane. (6.NS.C.6)

E43A4B151D204241B5E5EF89FD77CB8E.description: Students will demonstrate knowledge of the coordinate plane by graphing a) independent and dependent variables, b) positive and negative coordinates and c) polygons with given lengths.

C191351D02EB448E8D14DC371698D594.description: Write and solve one-step inequalities given real world problems. Interpret the solution in the context of the problem (including possible rounding and using appropriate units). (7.EE.B.4.B)

5D0415A16BE64E55BC568065C12B7787.description: Solve one-step inequalities in the form of px>q, px<q, pxq, and pxq, where p and q are rational numbers (including reversing the inequality symbol when multiplying or dividing by a negative number), and graph the solutions on a number line. (7.EE.B.4.B)

06C465DAF551409EA83FA994E6E45385.description: Solve one-step inequalities in the form of x + p > q, x + p < q, x + p  q, and x + p  q, where p and q are rational numbers, and graph the solutions on a number line. (7.EE.B.4.B)

405C531D62AE4FF58729C370818846CC.description: Demonstrate understanding that inequalities have infinite solutions by identifying individual solutions to the inequality. (6.EE.B.8)

5048695F4A3F47C087FABB2308EB83A0.description: Write and graph inequalities of the form x>c, x

61882B847D3D4F4AAB8C22CA273116BD.description: Translate between words and inequalities, given a mathematical or real world problem. (6.EE.B.8)

AF93B92EDCD041A4A657F158B8A63524.description: Students will solve, interpret, and graph solutions to one-variable inequalities using rational numbers.

04AB237C09114220937947FE4277560E.description: Write and solve one-step equations given real world problems. Interpret the solution in the context of the problem (including possible rounding and using appropriate units). (6.EE.B.7)

8BE98F5003A14CAF818B0CB87C2086F2.description: Solve two step equations in the form of px + q = r, where p, q, and r are integers. (6.EE.B.7)

93CB2FCFD5A0408C991F21FE5D584847.description: Solve one-step equations in the form of px=q, where p and q are rational numbers. (6.EE.B.7)

FB72EA74578A4EF6A623437DF1624D0D.description: Solve one-step equations in the form of x+p=q, where p and q are rational numbers. (6.EE.B.7)

B6CCEE5C605343619C889FAA6D6C8BEC.description: Use substitution to determine whether a given value satisfies an equation. (6.EE.B.5)

2ECD776E18BF4335A4E37F9800E98228.description: Students will solve and interpret solutions to one-variable equations using rational numbers, represent and analyze relationships between variables in two-variable equations, and solve two-step equations using integers.

73BFB6D4EFE34D1AB503A32C1410D1B6.description: Write and evaluate expressions involving integers, using the four mathematical operations, and interpret the solution in the context of real world problems. (7.NS.A.1.B., 7.NS.A.1.C.)

4E10957BD13B4368B1CA195D666257B2.description: Multiply and divide integers, and interpret the solution in the context of real world problems. (7.NS.A.2.A, 7.NS.A.2.B)

D60BF01A64924F2E8A7FE809530E10B6.description: Subtract integers, using the additive inverse property when appropriate, and interpret the solution in the context of real world problems. (7.NS.A.1.C)

A7A7040FAF99446BBE767E66493AAF23.description: Add integers, using absolute values when appropriate, and interpret the solution in the context of real world problems. (7.NS.A.1.B)

056E427650C44504A4DE14B7666C9D14.description: Students will perform operations involving integers to solve mathematical and real world problems.

62C4A712AAF34B01A190B225D158B8F0.description: Compare, order, and interpret integers and absolute values (including magnitude) in real world problems. (6.NS.C.7.B., 6.NS.C.7.C, 6.NS.C.7.D)

55675AADC71A40ADB26B37A1B9E302EF.description: Find the absolute value of a number by determining its distance from zero on a number line. (6.NS.C.7.C)

96A471C939B64D8B9BE074FB7B9DEBFF.description: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram. (6.NS.C.7.A)

C8B7163AE0E24A2B9B840C47E80EA914.description: Determine the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself. For example -(-3) = 3. (6.NS.C.6.A)

03E4652F36F04736861B055AB8CFD268.description: Describe the relationship between numbers with opposite signs on a number line and demonstrate that the sum of opposites is zero in real world situations. (6.NS.C.6A, 7.NS.A.1.A)

4B61FBA568DF4CA98A09CB4CA5A482C1.description: Plot points on a number line that represent integers and other rational numbers. (6.NS.C.6)

9DCA026C860645ECA9C9A035393DD315.description: Students will compare and order integers, as well as find and interpret absolute value, in order to solve mathematical and real world problems.

C87CDBB6B4CE48FD9D6212901E93B9AC.description: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units (including conversion factors within, and between, the U.S. customary and metric systems). (6.RP.A.3.D)

7AB5C83BCBE44693BE391E9EA12B2F3F.description: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30/100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent. (6.RP.A.3.C)

39861402656C4FCB9368EF727D984114.description: Solve mathematical and real world rate problems by finding the unit rate, analyzing a equivalent ratio table, and/or by plotting and analyzing its corresponding graph. (6.RP.A.3.A, 6.RP.A.3.B)

7834150C3D454C50998FF439221E3E72.description: Use a ratio relationship to determine a unit rate and express the new relationship between the two quantities in words. For example, a recipe calls for 6 cups of flour per 2 cups of sugar, so it requires 3 cups of flour per 1 cup of sugar. (6.RP.A.2)

361E5803F60C491E8C0EC3D6C4908E16.description: Create and compare tables of equivalent ratios and relate quantities with whole number measurements, including finding a missing number in a ratio table. (6.RP.A.3.A)

22A14933AC614BA195D30417A1FEF039.description: Use ratio notation (colon, to, fraction) and ratio language to describe the relationship between two quantities in words. For example, the ratio of boys to girls in the classroom is 3:4, 3 to 4, , which means for every 3 boys, there are 4 girls. (6.RP.A.1)

A43CA1A554D34A4CB8146FB8B88DDE34.description: Students will use ratios and ratio concepts/reasoning to solve problems involving unit rates, percents, and converting measurements.

227BE4B3CF26468D944AB3B0AFE54E40.description: Find the volume of a rectangular prism with fractional edges by using unit cubes and/or the volume formula. (6.G.A.2)

C4677411585745E5A79A68E038366E0C.description: Find the surface area of triangular and rectangular prisms by decomposing into triangular or rectangular faces. (6.G.A.4)

B26B8E5A45254BEA892AEE1805764ACA.description: Find the area of composite figures by decomposing into triangles and quadrilaterals. (6.G.A.1)

B5DF82A7020C4617A08E25BCC2439B45.description: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, and special quadrilaterals (parallelogram, trapezoid, rhombus). (6.G.A.1)

CD165AF2226A4668810BD34BA06D5638.description: Students will solve mathematical and real-world problems involving area (rectangles, triangles, trapezoids, and resulting composite figures), surface area (pyramids and prisms) and volume (rectangular prisms).

04A64C76A14245B792618D932B202243.description: Convert between fractions, decimals, and percents. (WS)

D3F40B33BAD34171BFD3F004BDB6D421.description: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals (including dividing with decimals in the divisor) using the standard algorithm for each operation and use estimation to determine reasonableness of answer. (6.NS.B.3)

CBFBBDC79C96410AAE1959DE2ACF8C1C.description: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving division of fractions. (6.NS.A.1)

8D0A519314A64D63B0B168D59AB28220.description: Compute and interpret products and quotients of fractions and mixed numbers, using the relationship (a/b)(c/d)=ad/bcand a visual model. (6.NS.A.1)

70427D7C473C4F56BF0FFF66308EF60A.description: Students will multiply and divide positive fractions and fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide positive decimals numbers.

04374719CCB54525BA1D255A1B5A0A48.description: Identify when two algebraic expressions are equivalent by substituting a value for the variable or applying one of the properties of operations. (6.EE.A.4)

568165856CCF4F658F04426C9E77D076.description: Identify and apply the properties of operations (commutative, associative, distributive) to generate equivalent algebraic expressions and solve numerical expressions. (6.EE.A.3)

3431FE605096464F9EC0AC34DF79A3D8.description: Write numerical or algebraic expressions given real world problems. (6.EE.A.1, 6.EE.A.2, 6.EE.A.6)

A55D2EC80A744E72897C5FEF4AC2397E.description: Evaluate/simplify numerical and algebraic expressions involving whole number exponents, including substituting for a given value in formulas. (6.EE.A.1, 6.EE.A.2.A, 6.EE.A.2.C)

6326EA32667B4DB393C4679C15DCCE4E.description: Translate between words and algebraic expressions and identify parts of algebraic expressions. (6.EE.A.1, 6.EE.A.2.B, 6.EE.A.2.C)

008117B6083844209982D9DA86F0C7E0.description: Students will write and evaluate expressions, as well as identify and generate equivalent expressions by utilizing the properties of operations.
